awd_abstract_narration:
The projects to be supported by this CAREER award center on analyzing distances in random environments. Some examples include finding travel times on road systems with random traffic, the minimal number of connections between people in social media graphs, and generally the total cost of moving from one place to another in a medium where microscopic distances are unknown. The research questions are combined with educational activities, like summer workshops on probability theory for young researchers, summer projects with undergraduates, and funding for a postdoctoral researcher. The proposed work has connections to other areas of mathematical physics, like the structure of disordered magnets, and satisfaction problems from computer science.

This proposal details projects in probability theory and mathematical physics, specifically in statistical mechanics. The main models are percolation models and first-passage percolation (FPP), and the questions are to analyze the extreme values of collections of random variables that are highly correlated. In FPP, the main observable is the travel time from one node of a network to another one in a random environment, and we plan to study the asymptotics and fluctuations of this travel time, along with the structure of minimizers (geodesics) and near-minimizers. Much of the research will involve Busemann functions, which are tools from metric geometry used to study parallelism of geodesic rays. It is expected that results obtained in these studies will have consequences in spatial growth and epidemic models, other percolation problems, disordered spin systems, and polymer models. The proposed work includes an educational component, with funds for a postdoctoral researcher, summer workshops, and summer projects for undergraduates.

por.por_cntn:
This project covered questions in probability theory and mathematical physics, specifically percolation models and random growth models. The main percolation model considered was first-passage percolation (FPP), which can model the spread of bacteria, or the flow of fluid in a porous media. Given a grid or lattice, one places random numbers (speeds) on the edges, an a bacterial colony started at one vertex of the grid spreads along the edges according to the random speeds. One main question addressed in this project is the geometry of the infected region at a given large time t. The PI and collaborators showed that under general conditions, the boundary typically has size of order t^{d-1}, where d is the dimension of the underlying space. This indicates that the boundary is relatively smooth.

Another question addressed in the project is the geometry of optimal infection paths, or geodesics. These are the fastest paths that an infection can take to get from one location to another. It has been predicted that in many growth models, there are no "doubly-infinite" geodesics, or paths that are infinite in both directions, each segment of which is a geodesic. The PI and collaborators can the first progress on this question under general conditions for dimensions 3 and higher, showing that if these bigeodesics do exist, they cannot be constructed in a natural manner. This gives strong evidence that the above prediction is true.

Another set of questions from this project concerned Bernoulli percolation models. In this setting, one takes a grid and removes each edge with probability 1/2 and retains each edge with probability 1/2, independently. The resulting subgrid does not have any infinite paths, but there are large finite ones. A major question is to determine the shortest resulting path connecting two sides of a large box. If the box has sidelength n, it is predicted that the shortest path connecting the sides has length of order n^a for some a bigger than 1. The PI and collaborators showed that this a is strictly less than 4/3. This is progress toward verifying the numerical estimate a = 1.13... that exists in the physics literature.

The educational component of this project involved mentoring and organizing a conference. The PI mentored 3 graduate students and 3 postdocs in research in probability. The grant funded some of their research and travel to conferences. The PI also mentored several undergraduate students in reading courses or undergraduate research projects. The PI coorganized the conference "Recent Trends in Continuous and Discrete Probability" with C. Houdr?. The conference ran for 4 days and consisted of 2 minicourses and 10-20 research lectures. There were also several short talks given by graduate students and postdoctoral attendees.
